content.title: Temperature & Humidity Requirements for Mourning Geckos
content.content: Mourning geckos inhabit tropical rainforests where temperatures remain moderate (70-85°F) and humidity stays consistently high (60-80%). Unlike many reptiles, they are sensitive to heat and can die from temperatures above 85°F. Proper temperature and humidity control is non-negotiable for this species - getting these parameters wrong will result in lethal heat stress or dehydration.

Mourning geckos require a vertical temperature gradient with gentle warmth at the top and cooler areas below. This allows them to thermoregulate by moving up or down. Crepuscular activity means they bask briefly at sunset/sunrise, not for extended periods like diurnal species.

content.text: Temperature Requirements by Zone:

content.content: CRITICAL LIMIT: Temperatures consistently above 85°F are LETHAL to mourning geckos. Heat stress sets in quickly at 85-90°F, and death can occur within hours at 90°F+. NEVER exceed 85°F basking temperature.

COLD LIMIT: Temperatures at or below 72°F for extended periods (days/weeks) cause metabolic slowdown, immune suppression, and illness. Brief nighttime dips to 65°F are acceptable, but daytime lows should not drop below 70°F.
Because mourning geckos require LOW heat, standard reptile basking bulbs (50-75w) are far too powerful. Low-wattage bulbs with dimmers are essential for fine control.

content.text: Heat Source Comparison:

rows: BEST - mimics natural sunlight, gentle heat
Nighttime supplemental heat only if needed
Insufficient for arboreal species (can't reach top)

content.content: Recommended setup: 25w incandescent bulb in 5.5-inch dome fixture with ceramic socket + plug-in lamp dimmer. Start with dimmer at 50% and adjust based on temperature gun readings.
Proper heat lamp positioning creates a safe basking area without overheating the entire enclosure.

content.text: Placement Guidelines:

rows: Creates gradient - warm side vs cool side
Comfortable resting spot directly under lamp
Plastic melts, ceramic handles heat safely

content.content: NEVER place heat lamp in the center of the enclosure top - this creates uniform heat with no cool retreat. Always position over one side to maintain a thermal gradient.

Plug-in lamp dimmers are ESSENTIAL for mourning gecko setups because room temperature, seasonal changes, and enclosure insulation all affect final basking temperature. A dimmer allows real-time adjustment.

content.text: Dimmer vs Thermostat:

rows: BEST for low-wattage bulbs (25w), prevents overheating
Automated dimming based on probe reading
Advanced option if room temps fluctuate significantly
Cycles power on/off to maintain temperature
Not ideal for low-wattage bulbs (causes flickering)

content.content: Setup Process: 1) Install 25w bulb in fixture, 2) Plug fixture into dimmer, 3) Set dimmer to 50%, 4) Wait 30 minutes, 5) Measure basking spot with temp gun, 6) Adjust dimmer up/down to achieve 80-85°F, 7) Recheck after 1 hour and finalize setting.
Accurate temperature monitoring prevents heat stress and ensures proper thermal gradients.

content.text: Measurement Tools & Methods:

rows: Point at basking perch, substrate, branches - instant reading
Secure probe to basking surface with heat-safe tape
Place probe mid-height in center of enclosure
DO NOT USE - readings often 5-10°F off

content.content: Daily Checks: Use temp gun to spot-check basking area (should be 80-85°F), mid-zone branches (75-78°F), and substrate level (70-75°F). Check at same time each day after lights have been on for 1+ hour.
Turn off all heat sources at night unless room temperature drops below 65°F. Mourning geckos benefit from a natural nighttime temperature drop.

content.text: Nighttime Heating Protocol:

rows: Turn off all lights and heat
Increase ventilation, use small fan nearby (not directly on enclosure)

content.content: Natural nighttime temperature drop (72°F day ? 65-68°F night) is HEALTHY and mimics tropical rainforest conditions. Do not maintain daytime temperatures 24/7.
Mourning geckos require consistently high humidity (60-80%) to prevent dehydration and support shedding. Low humidity (<50%) causes stuck shed, dehydration, and respiratory irritation.

content.text: Target Humidity Levels:

rows: After morning misting, gradual decline throughout day
Increase misting frequency when geckos appear dull

content.content: Humidity should fluctuate naturally between 60-80% throughout the day. Constant 90%+ humidity with no dry-out period causes respiratory infections and mold. Allow humidity to drop to 60-65% before next misting.
Misting serves two purposes: providing drinking water (mourning geckos lick droplets) and maintaining ambient humidity.

content.text: Misting Schedule:

rows: Drinking opportunity, raise humidity after night
Only if humidity drops below 55% in dry climates

content.content: Misting Technique: Use pump-style pressure sprayer (not spray bottle - insufficient mist). Target foliage and branches heavily (geckos drink from leaves), lightly mist substrate edges. Avoid soaking substrate until muddy. Mist from multiple angles to create droplets on all surfaces.
Water source matters: Use tap water or spring water (contains essential minerals). NEVER use distilled or RO water - lack of minerals can cause deficiencies over time.

content.text: Problem-Solving Guide:

rows: Wattage too high or dimmer setting too high
Lower dimmer setting or switch to lower wattage bulb (15-20w)
Room too hot or insufficient ventilation
Increase ventilation, use small fan nearby, lower ambient AC
Increase dimmer setting or add secondary low-wattage heat source
Insufficient misting or too much ventilation
Increase misting frequency, partially cover screen top with glass
Reduce misting amount, ensure screen top is not covered, add small fan
IMMEDIATE: Turn off heat, mist heavily, lower ambient temp. Check basking temp!
Ensure daytime temps reach 75-78°F, check nighttime doesn't drop below 65°F

content.content: Heat stress symptoms (gaping mouth, excessive climbing to top, lethargy): Turn off all heat sources IMMEDIATELY, mist enclosure heavily, move to cooler room. Heat stress can kill within hours - this is an emergency.
Room temperatures change with seasons, requiring adjustments to maintain proper enclosure parameters.

content.text: Seasonal Monitoring:

rows: Basking area too warm, difficulty cooling
Lower dimmer setting, increase ventilation, AC if needed
Entire enclosure too cool, high nighttime drop
Increase dimmer setting, add nighttime CHE if needed
Check temps daily, adjust dimmer as needed
Increase misting frequency, add moisture-retaining d°cor (live plants)

content.content: Pro tip: Re-check enclosure temperatures and humidity every time seasons change or you adjust home heating/cooling. What works in summer may overheat in winter when home heating is active.
